title: Contributing to nycOpenData
text: can help : Reporting bugs confusing behavior. Suggesting improvements documentation examples. Adding wrappers additional NYC Open Data datasets. Improving tests edge-case handling (timeouts, API errors, schema changes). Improving performance developer ergonomics.

title: Contributing to nycOpenData
text: Please open issue : expected happen actually happened minimal reproducible example (copy/paste-able using reprex package). sessionInfo() output. issue dataset-specific, include: dataset name /NYC Open Data dataset ID (e.g., erm2-nwe9). filters used function call. Whether issue intermittent (likely related rate limits timeouts).

Secrets: Ensure record sensitive API keys tokens cassettes.

title: Getting Started with nycOpenData
text: NYC population almost 8.5 million people. calling 311, residents able make comments, inquiries, complaints, requests city agencies. 311 service requests contained dataset, found . R, nycOpenData package can used pull data directly. nycOpenData package provides streamlined interface accessing New York City’s vast open data resources. connects directly NYC Open Data Portal. currently utilized primary tool teaching data acquisition Reproducible Research Using R, helping students bridge gap raw city APIs tidy data analysis. using nyc_311() function, can gather recent 311 calls New York City, filter based upon columns inside dataset. Note: nyc_311() automatically sorts descending order based created_date column.

title: Getting Started with nycOpenData
text: start, let’s pull small sample see data looks like. default, function pulls 10,000 recent requests, however, let’s change see latest 3 requests. , can set limit = 3. Fantastic! successfully pulled 311 data NYC Open Data Portal. Let’s now take example last 3 requests borough Brooklyn. nyc_311() function can filter based columns dataset. filter, add filters = list() put whatever filters like inside. colnames call , know column called “borough” can use accomplish . Success! calling brooklyn_311 dataset see 3 rows data, unique() call see borough featured dataset BROOKLYN. One strongest qualities function ability filter based multiple columns. Let’s put everything together get dataset last 50 311 requests New York Police Department Brooklyn. successfully created dataset contains 50 recent requests regarding NYPD borough Brooklyn.

title: Summary
text: nycOpenData package provides unified, tidy interface New York City Open Data portal. wrapping 40 distinct municipal datasets—ranging 311 service requests Department Buildings job applications—package abstracts complexities SODA (Socrata Open Data API) consistent set R functions. function returns standardized tibble, supporting seamless integration tidyverse-based data science workflows.

title: Summary
text: New York City maintains one comprehensive open data portals world. However, researchers students often face barriers accessing data, including navigating diverse endpoint identifiers, managing API rate limits, cleaning raw JSON responses. general-purpose Socrata wrappers exist, require users manually specify API endpoints handle domain-specific data types. nycOpenData addresses challenges providing curated wrappers high-impact datasets used urban research. package currently core pedagogical component curriculum ‘Reproducible Research Using R’, serves primary tool teaching automated data acquisition. 500 downloads date, package demonstrated significant utility academic practitioner environments.

title: Summary
text: Curated Access: Wrappers 40+ datasets including TLC records, crime statistics, environmental data. Reproducibility: Integrated vcr package mocked HTTP testing, allowing research pipelines verified offline. Tidy Format: Every function ensures date-time strings, numeric values, logical flags correctly parsed R types upon arrival.

text: author thanks NYC Open Data team maintaining underlying infrastructure users ‘Reproducible Research Using R’ ongoing feedback testing.

title: DOHMH New York City Restaurant Inspection Results — nyc_restaurant_inspection_results
text: dataset contains every sustained yet adjudicated violation citation every full special program inspection conducted three years prior recent inspection restaurants college cafeterias active status RECORD DATE (date data pull). inspection results one violation, values associated fields repeated additional violation record. Establishments uniquely identified CAMIS (record ID) number. Keep mind thousands restaurants start business go business every year; restaurants active status included dataset. Records also included restaurant applied permit yet inspected inspections resulting violations. Establishments inspection date 1/1/1900 new establishments yet received inspection. Restaurants received violations represented single row coded violations using ACTION field. dataset compiled several large administrative data systems, contains illogical values result data entry transfer errors. Data may also missing. dataset information Health Department’s Restaurant Grading website come data source. Health Department’s Restaurant Grading website : http://www1.nyc.gov/site/doh/services/restaurant-grades.page See data dictionary file Attachments section OpenData website summary data fields allowable values.

title: nycOpenData 0.1.5
text: CRAN release: 2026-01-25

title: nycOpenData 0.1.5
text: Added new vignette, “Working NYC 311 Data”, demonstrating end--end, reproducible workflow accessing, filtering, visualizing NYC 311 service requests using nyc_311(). vignette available package website via vignette("nyc-311", package = "nycOpenData"). Updated nyc_311() explicitly target NYC 311 Service Requests dataset covering 2020–present, aligning function current primary NYC Open Data endpoint. Added new function, nyc_311_2010_2019(), providing access historical NYC 311 service request data 2010–2019, maintained separate dataset NYC Open Data platform.

title: nycOpenData 0.1.5
text: Continued improvements internal request handling reliability consistency interacting live NYC Open Data APIs. Updated documentation examples ensure robust behavior CRAN checks preserving reproducible workflows interactive use. breaking changes existing function interfaces.
